item.title: Whats Wrong With This Code?
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“S C A R Bot, post:9, topic:138062”]Just add in boolean process

[code]public int onesALogin = 0;

if(playerLevel[3] > 99 && onesALogin == 1) {
addItem(7352656546547, 1);
onesALogin = 1;
}[/code][/quote]

I think you mean != in your if ( ) line.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats Wrong With This Code?
item.dc:creator: @krawks12 krawks12
item.description:
@krawks12 wrote:

[quote=“S C A R Bot, post:9, topic:138062”]Just add in boolean process

[code]public int onesALogin = 0;

if(playerLevel[3] > 99 && onesALogin == 1) {
addItem(7352656546547, 1);
onesALogin = 1;
}[/code][/quote]

Why do u think servers keep getting laggier and laggier? Because of putting it in your process. Your client is written in a way if you read it over well that the only thing needed in your process for the msot part is timers++; and timers–; with other small exceptions.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats Wrong With This Code?
item.dc:creator: @ownage_plz ownage plz
item.description:
@ownage_plz wrote:

FYI You don’t need the one’s in bold.

else if ([b]([/b]command.equalsIgnoreCase("hpcape") && [b]([/b]getLevelForXP(playerXP[3]) == 99) { sendMessage("You have 99 hp you got the achievement Cape!"); addItem(7623,1); addItem(7624,1); }

Read full topic

item.title: Whats Wrong With This Code?
item.dc:creator: @Legend1 -Legend-
item.description:
@Legend1 wrote:

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:5, topic:138062”][quote author=Steph. link=topic=189741.msg1711250#msg1711250 date=1188365326]

else if (command.startsWith("hpcape") && getLevelForXP(playerXP[3]) == 99) { sendMessage("You have 99 hp you got the achievement Cape!"); addItem(7623,1); addItem(7624,1); }

That should work
[/quote]

No, you fail. This is correct:

else if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("hpcape")) && getLevelForXP(playerXP[3] == 99)) { sendMessage("You have 99 hp you got the achievement Cape!"); addItem(7623,1); addItem(7624,1); }

Never use startsWith unless you need to read an additional String after the command.
Add more parentheses so the logical AND operator knows exactly what two booleans to compare.

@ original poster, never use an assignment operator = to compare integers. You use ==[/quote]

You wouldn’t use double parenthesis, only 1 for ) for both.

else if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("hpcape") && getLevelForXP(playerXP[3]) == 99)
{
sendMessage("You have 99 hp you got the achievement Cape!");
addItem(7623,1);
addItem(7624,1);
}

Srsly.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats Wrong With This Code?
item.dc:creator: @ownage_plz ownage plz
item.description:
@ownage_plz wrote:

Why use the extra parenthesis.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats Wrong With This Code?
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“Steph., post:3, topic:138062”]else if (command.startsWith("hpcape") && getLevelForXP(playerXP[3]) == 99) { sendMessage("You have 99 hp you got the achievement Cape!"); addItem(7623,1); addItem(7624,1); }

That should work[/quote]

No, you fail. This is correct:

else if ((command.equalsIgnoreCase("hpcape")) && (getLevelForXP(playerXP[3]) == 99)) { sendMessage("You have 99 hp you got the achievement Cape!"); addItem(7623,1); addItem(7624,1); }

Never use startsWith unless you need to read an additional String after the command.
Add more parentheses so the logical AND operator knows exactly what two booleans to compare.

@ original poster, never use an assignment operator = to compare integers. You use ==

Read full topic
